Combining great gun design, from Tripwire Interactive, and an addictive wave-by-wave zombie-style shooter, Killing Floor gives you a run for more than your money. It gives you a great run for the Trader when the wave has ended and a mad rush to whatever player is liberally sprinkling the ground with "dosh". With 6 upgradable classes to choose from, you can knock down your moaning enemies one by one as a sniper, in a great big boom as a demolitionist or any which way you choose! When the wave ends, you rush to the Trader (She alternates where she is so you have to check where the hell you are going) and buy better, faster, bigger weapons to blast even better, faster, bigger enemies back to where they came from! 8/10

A Fun Game I Recommend That You Have a bunch of friends that have the game

Just good stupid fun. I picked this up for maybe 5 bucks long ago, and I've played it to death. Something about it just clicks. It's ancient, it's clunky, and it's often unfair. But maybe these things make what works work better. the gunplay is fairly solid, lag generally very good (and posted on the server list, another antiquity amongst matchmaking games), and the zombies varied but easily recognized (for the most part). I'm sure there's better coop zombie-genocide simulators around (they're a staple of CoD games), but for the money this is hard to beat.

The british accents add miles to the game's personality. It wouldve been boring as hell with beefy american guy voices.

What this game lacks in glamor, it makes up for in game-play and execution! Right from the start this game throws the player into the driver's seat. No need for a drawn out tutorial, an unnecessary single player campaign or overly complicated controls, the player is tossed into the mix with minimal delay and given nothing more than a set of legs to run with, weapons, and monsters that need killing!

The game is built off of survival multiplayer co-op. There are a number of classes that can be leveled up to improve the stats for the player's weapons, health and armor; consequently, a slight rpg system is implemented. It is the given ability to level up that makes the higher difficulties a thrill and worth the many hours of replay this game offers. The different classes can offer a diverse team build.

The weapons are numerous and extremely satisfactory! The few equipment option are also well made. All players are given a door welder, one class gets a buff for it, that can be used to seal doors from attacking hordes. To many survival games lack the option to barricade doors. *cough* Aliens: Colonial Marines *cough*

There are so many levels to choose from -- official and community made. Each map feels unique. Some of the player made maps are given twists, but the basic idea to all the maps is to survive and kill.

Over all, it is the simplicity of this game that makes it so good. Everything is does, it does well! Even now this game is worth well over $20

Не  каждой игре  для успеха требуется  много времени и  денег  на разработку,не каждой нужна суперлеалистичная графика и  уж точно не  всем нужна реклама  по тв.  Killing Floor как раз одна из таких  игр.Избитая идея выживания работает как всегда отлично.Есть  вы,ваша команда, магазин  в котором можно купить оружие на деньги выпадающие из монстров ,сами монстры ну и  босс которого  вы встретите в финале.Возможно  это и  не иновационно,но это не главное,главное что  весело.А уж веселья  игре не занимать -рубить и стрелять в  монстров  не надоедает достаточно  долго ну а    замедление времени  (которое к сожалению врубается произвольно и  иногда в самый неподходящий момент)приносит что то новое,как впрочем и   постоянные длс с оружием(карты  добавляют бесплатно,а вот  за  скины персонажей тоже придется заплатить,хотя их много и не совсем понятно зачем покупать еще)  ну  и еще тематические наряды(когда монсров наряжают  в костюмы предстоящего  праздника)  продлевают интерес комьюнити к игре .


Killing Floor  далеко  не идеальна и уж точно   не тянет на звание   лучшего  интерактивного развлечения(та же Л4Д  гораздо лучше )но всетаки затянуть  вас часов на 20  она определенно  сможет,а это уже  достижение.
Оценка-7/10 баллов.

This game is beyond awesome! The biggest fun you will get from it if playing with friends in coop. On the other hand, there are MANY servers full of people playing this game! Those servers have SO MUCH goodies like walking personal bots assisting you in killing spicemen and healing you, or turrets or new types of perks. People have advanced that game and added more different creatures and monsters whom you will have to deal with. 

This game is so enjoyable, it is all about active action survival! Imagine you and several of your wounded teammates stuck in the corner pushed by mutated creatures, and you are healing each other and trying to stay strong, then you move along the map behind obstacles avoiding and shooting monsters from covers! And when you are done with one way, you have limited time to shop for new ammo! RUN FOR SHOP QUICKLY or you are screwed! So much adrenaline so much action, awesome soundtracks! 

It's worth buying this game.

Killing floor is a fun game, Ive logged over 300 hours. Its good in the beginning but it gets boring after a while. Its just wave after wave of zombies, if you like that youll never get tired of it. The only other downside to same thing over again are teammates, achievements and leveliing up. It takes forever to level up after reaching level 3. Certain achievements you can only get during seasons where the game changes or they ask for ridiculous things. And teammates-pshh if your team sucks or is low level, youre either gonna lose or carry the team. Overall, I liked it, its fun, I recommend it, I just think they couldve done more with it

The game has all the problems that any horde game would have. It's all wave based, monsters just come at you and you shoot them. There isn't much more to it - it's all very monotone.
The good news? It is pretty much the best horde-wave-defence-thing-a-majig-a-thon there is. The heads of zeds pop in a red mess of satisfaction, all weapons feel fairly good to use, team work yields most success. Game's great, will ruin your life.

Tripware Interactive knows the difference between quantity vs quality. Instead of releasing a great game, forget about it, & plan to make a "better" sequel (like most developers do today), they update the game every now and then to add some flavor into the mix for everyone.

With season updates, interesting dlc (uncommon now a days), and amazing player created content available through Steam Workshop. There is enough content to last this game for another couple of decades or more.

My first paid Steam game (gifted) and my first favorite PC game since I registered on Steam back in 2010.

A must have for every horror fan.

10/10.

This is an awesome zombie survival! It's better as a multiplayer rather than playing by yourself, but either way you can enjoy it. I love the objectives and store features (the store is a little unrealistic, but what the hell)
I would recomend this game to anyone who loves playing with friends and zombie survival games.

This is quite honestly the best Horde Mode you can play today. Or atleast one of the best. Don't know what a horde mode is? Basically It's a coop throw away mode devs make alot. where a small group of friends( or bastards who joined and have no idea what the word teamwork means) get together and take on waves of monsters. often zombies.To make an entire game that is 90% horde mode is difficult. You would have to make it fun as hell, goofy at times, Intense, a wide variety of foes, and a good balance between teamwork being essential and relying on the behavior of other players who eventually start to act like total trolls. Killing Floor does all of that. let me just say now that, past beginner difficulty, this game is a challenge to say the least. Your experience of the match can vary based on the tweaks made by the server admin. A full on totally customizable sandbox menu lets you change everything like the specimens you face, waves you go through, and of course a wide variety of maps each being even better than the last. Like all horde modes, your experience would be very very dull unless you got to play with fun toys. KF offers a neat "traders store" between rounds. Where you can buy guns, armor, ammo, and if you like change your chosen perk. Perks can give you discounts and bonuses on many different things but the big thing is each perk you have offers It's own weaponry. If I have the Berzerker perk I'll mostly only be able to get melee weapons. If I want a shotgun or a m4 or something like that I'll need a specific perk. Choose wisely though because You can only change once between rounds. If you are easily offended by an onslaught of microtransactions and DLC, KF might just piss you off. As one can dissect from the selection of DLC it showcases in game and in the tore page, there is blatant  use of the sort. for example, you start off with about 5 different character skins to choose from. There are litterally atleast 7x more skins available so long as you got the cash. the same can be said about guns. If you can learn to ignore all these, you can still have a more than satisfying experience while not paying a dime over the cost of the game.

pros:
-fun as hell  -intense  -satisfying mechanics and usually good players to play with
-solo mode  -fully customizable experience

cons:
- load of DLC and microtransaction.  -maybe a little too hard for some
-can be hard to get a good game going -visuals often below average being a game from 2009(granted still easy on the eyes)
-joining a lobby in game can be a chore with a small amount of euros and a damn pistol to use.

overall a refreshing experience that leaves one very satisfied, a game worth the price of admission. [7.9/10]

A kind of old but really fun game. Although there are a ton of guns and plenty of zombies to shoot, it requires a bit more thought and action than just shooting everything that looks remotely like a zombie.

Knowing when and how to run is extremely important, and if you're planning on living, you better be ready to make a run for it, as well as not shoot certain things at certain times... many noobs have gotten killed repeatedly after pissing off a scrake or fleshpound, including me.

You should also know before buying that there are no crosshairs in game; if you want to know where the hell you're aiming you have to use the sights. Using the sights slows you down greatly. Because of this, the skill of making hip shots can be useful, depending on your class.

Speaking of classes, the game has seven, each of which ranks up with certain actions/weapons. The game gets much easier as they reach higher ranks.

One last thing: the beginner difficulty is too easy. Most players could probably survive it while smashing their face on the keyboard and randomly shooting. If you want to stay a noob forever, stay in beginner. But if you want to get better, start in normal and work your way up. It might be suicide with a level 0 perk, but normal will teach you how the game really works.
